quiz.title: Unit 3: Motion & Graphs (Quiz 4)
quiz.subtitle: Core Motion Concepts and Definitions (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Distance, Displacement, Speed, Velocity, and Acceleration

questions.question: Which of the following best defines motion?
options: The change in position of an object over time
The speed at which an object travels
The force required to move an object
questions.explanation: Motion is defined as the change in an object's position relative to a reference point over time.

questions.question: What is the difference between distance and displacement?
options: Distance is always greater than displacement
Distance is a vector quantity, displacement is scalar
Distance measures total path length, displacement measures change in position
They are the same physical quantity
questions.explanation: Distance is the total path length traveled (scalar), while displacement is the straight-line change in position from start to end (vector).

questions.question: A car travels 40 km north, then 30 km south. What is the total distance traveled?
questions.explanation: Distance is the sum of all path lengths: 40 km + 30 km = 70 km.

questions.question: A car travels 40 km north, then 30 km south. What is the displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement is the net change in position: 40 km north - 30 km south = 10 km north.

questions.question: What is the key difference between speed and velocity?
options: Speed is always faster than velocity
Velocity includes direction, speed does not
Speed is a vector quantity, velocity is scalar
They are measured in different units
questions.explanation: Speed is scalar (magnitude only), velocity is vector (magnitude and direction).

questions.question: A runner completes one lap around a 400 m track in 50 seconds. What is their average speed?
questions.explanation: Average speed = total distance / time = 400 m / 50 s = 8 m/s.

questions.question: A runner completes one lap around a 400 m track in 50 seconds. What is their average velocity?
questions.explanation: Average velocity = displacement / time. Since they return to the starting point, displacement = 0, so velocity = 0 m/s.

questions.question: Which quantity is defined as the rate of change of velocity?
questions.explanation: Acceleration is the rate at which velocity changes with time.

questions.question: A car's velocity changes from 20 m/s to 30 m/s in 5 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (final velocity - initial velocity) / time = (30 - 20) m/s / 5 s = 2 m/s².

questions.question: Which of the following represents negative acceleration?
questions.explanation: Negative acceleration (deceleration) occurs when an object slows down in its direction of motion.

questions.question: If an object has zero acceleration, what can we say about its motion?
options: It is moving at constant velocity
questions.explanation: Zero acceleration means no change in velocity - the object moves at constant speed in a straight line.

questions.question: A bicycle travels 150 meters in 30 seconds. What is its average speed?
questions.explanation: Average speed = distance / time = 150 m / 30 s = 5 m/s.

questions.question: What does the slope of a position-time graph represent?
questions.explanation: The slope of a position-time graph equals the velocity of the object.

questions.question: A student walks 3 km east to school, then 3 km west back home. What is their total displacement?
questions.explanation: Displacement is the net change in position. Starting and ending at home means zero displacement.

questions.question: Which of the following is a vector quantity?
questions.explanation: Velocity has both magnitude and direction, making it a vector quantity.

questions.question: A car accelerates from rest to 25 m/s in 10 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (25 m/s - 0 m/s) / 10 s = 2.5 m/s².

questions.question: If velocity is constant, what is the acceleration?
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means no change in velocity, so acceleration is zero.

questions.question: A ball rolls down a hill, increasing its speed from 2 m/s to 8 m/s in 3 seconds. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration = (8 m/s - 2 m/s) / 3 s = 6 m/s / 3 s = 2 m/s².

questions.question: What is the SI unit of acceleration?
questions.explanation: Acceleration is change in velocity (m/s) per time (s), so units are m/s².

questions.question: A person walks 100 m north, then 100 m south. Their displacement is:
questions.explanation: They return to their starting position, so net displacement is zero.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of fundamental motion concepts.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! You understand the core ideas but should review vector vs. scalar quantities.
scoreMessages.50: A fair effort. Focus on the definitions of distance vs. displacement and speed vs. velocity.
scoreMessages.0: Keep trying! Review the basic definitions of motion, distance, displacement, speed, and velocity.
